As i understand it the plan is this:
 - computer controlled crossbar switch, connecting purely analog components to each other and D/A A/D converters
 - if some analog signal crosses some threshold the complete crossbar switch can be disconnect, meaning capacitors keep the state
 - computer can read out/modify/reprogramm
 - circuit calculates further
 - A/D log the signals you are interested in
 - Inter chip communication sends some analog signal over the wire/fiber, allowing to connect up as many analog chips as you can afford into any topology you want allowing you to simulate things really finely.

text:
How computation of an analog computer works:
An capacitor behaves like an integrator, you can add by connecting lines, there are multiplier circuits based operational amplifiers.

```
•<-"xdotdot"->| |<-"xdot"->| | <-"x"-> *-1 <-"-x"->•
```

The •s are connected. I gave the wires names.
Since xdotdot and -x are connected without any elements between them that means this circuit runs the differential equation d^2 x/dt^2 = -x.

So if the capacitors are loaded with some initial configuration this circuit (in the absence of resistance) simulates a sin/cos wave.

you have one wire representing dotwolf, one wire dotrabbit, which are connected to an capacitor each, giving you a wolf and rabbit wire, you can now use with multipliers and adders to make up the terms that define the RHS of the equation and connect it to the appropriate dot wire.

The notion of implicit vs explicit solvers doesn't exist as the electrons balance each other at the speed of electrons in wires.
DAEs are not any harder that ODEs (since you can add derivatives of any order since they are all just voltages.)
However you constrained by stiffness. If you want a calculation to happen at a certain precision all over your equation (you can trade precision for smaller capacitors that fill faster, so it runs faster) you need to have the necessary slowness at the thing with the biggest eigenvalue to, meaning the slowest part is λmax/ λmin slower than it could be when ran alone.

Thank you! Yes that sounds super cool! I was mostly confused on the crossbar and I'm still not sure why if some analog system crosses some threshold the crossbar system can disconnect.

I think my first encounter with analog computing simulating differential equations was where they simulated the Lorenz system using op amps and types of integrators/differentiators. I loved it! I've always wanted to build my own but never have. Super cool how the analog system can be just set up (wired up) and the topology of the circuit itself and all its integrators and differentiators to encode the dynamics. And the analog computer "simulates it itself" automatically by fulfilling the differential equations and running in real time. <http://seti.harvard.edu/unusual_stuff/misc/lorenz.htm|http://seti.harvard.edu/unusual_stuff/misc/lorenz.htm>

Im guessing that they encode DAEs in the following way? Though I haven't had any experience with DAEs but from what I understand its like an ODE with the diff. eqs, but there's also algebraic constraints on the state. I'm assuming maybe that the constraint equations can be encoded by using simple adding/summing/calculation circuits that ensure that the constraint equation holds. Like have DC voltages represent constants, 0 represents ground, and wire up the state wires using summing circuits/other analog computing circuits so that they constantly have to satisfy the algebraic equations. 

Then have this all in addition to the op amps differential equations. And the everything is solved using the dynamics of the circuit itself (Wow!).
